statement.text: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) is atherosclerotic occlusive disease affecting arteries outside the coronary, intracranial, and aortic circulation, primarily the lower extremity arteries. It is defined by an Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) ≤0.90 and manifests as a spectrum from asymptomatic disease to claudication to critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).
statement.formal: PAD: Atherosclerotic stenosis/occlusion of peripheral arteries | Diagnosis: ABI ≤0.90 | Spectrum: Asymptomatic → Claudication → Rest pain → Tissue loss (CLTI)

explanation.intuition: Think of PAD as 'blockages in the leg arteries' caused by the same disease process that causes heart attacks - atherosclerosis. Just as coronary artery disease restricts blood flow to the heart muscle, PAD restricts blood flow to the leg muscles and tissues. The legs need more blood during walking (exercise), so the first symptom is usually cramping during walking that improves with rest (claudication). If blockages become severe, the legs don't get enough blood even at rest, leading to pain and eventually tissue death.
explanation.key_insight: PAD is not just a leg problem - it's a marker of systemic atherosclerosis. Patients with PAD have a 4-6 fold increased risk of cardiovascular death compared to age-matched controls. Managing PAD means treating the whole patient's cardiovascular risk, not just the leg symptoms.
explanation.technical_details: The anatomic distribution of PAD reflects atherosclerosis predilection for arterial bifurcations: aortoiliac (30%), femoropopliteal (80-90%), and infrapopliteal (40-50%). Hemodynamically significant stenosis occurs when lumen is reduced by >50% diameter (>75% area). The ABI is the ratio of highest ankle systolic pressure to highest brachial systolic pressure; values ≤0.90 indicate PAD with sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 99% compared to angiography. Values <0.40 indicate severe disease.
common_misconceptions: PAD only affects the legs - upper extremity PAD also occurs
PAD is a benign condition - it carries major cardiovascular mortality risk
All PAD patients have claudication - many are asymptomatic
Low ABI means poor leg circulation only - it predicts cardiovascular events

definitions_glossary.peripheral_arterial_disease: Atherosclerotic disease of non-coronary, non-cerebral arteries
definitions_glossary.ankle_brachial_index: Ratio of ankle to brachial systolic blood pressure
definitions_glossary.claudication: Muscle pain induced by exercise, relieved by rest, due to arterial insufficiency
definitions_glossary.critical_limb_threatening_ischemia: Chronic ischemia with rest pain, ulcers, or gangrene threatening limb viability
definitions_glossary.atherosclerosis: Inflammatory disease with lipid deposition and arterial wall thickening
definitions_glossary.intermittent_claudication: Cramping leg pain that occurs with walking and resolves with rest

epidemiology.gender: Equal overall; claudication more common in men

atypical_leg_symptoms.description: Leg fatigue, difficulty walking, nonspecific discomfort

classic_claudication.description: Reproducible muscle pain with exertion, relieved by rest

definition.@value: Atherosclerotic occlusive disease of peripheral arteries, primarily affecting the lower extremities, diagnosed by ABI ≤0.90

sources.citation: Gerhard-Herman MD, et al. 2016 AHA/ACC Guideline on the Management of Patients With Lower Extremity Peripheral Artery Disease. Circulation. 2017;135(12):e686-e725.
Conte MS, et al. Global Vascular Guidelines on the Management of Chronic Limb-Threatening Ischemia. J Vasc Surg. 2019;69(6S):3S-125S.

learning_objectives: Define peripheral arterial disease and its diagnostic criteria
Describe the clinical spectrum from asymptomatic to CLTI
Identify major risk factors for PAD
Understand PAD as a marker of systemic cardiovascular risk
Calculate and interpret the ankle-brachial index
common_errors: Missing asymptomatic PAD - remember to check ABI in high-risk patients
Treating PAD as just a leg problem - it's a cardiovascular disease marker
Equating PAD with claudication - most patients are asymptomatic
Not considering PAD in diabetic patients with 'neuropathic' foot ulcers
clinical_pearls: ABI <0.90 is diagnostic; <0.40 indicates severe disease
PAD patients die of heart attacks more than from leg problems
Every PAD patient needs aggressive cardiovascular risk modification
Walking exercise programs can double walking distance in claudicants

medicalCode.description: Atherosclerosis of native arteries of extremities
